issue.title: duration<double> should not implicitly convert to duration<int>

discussion.p: The following code should not compile because it involves implicit truncation errors (against the design philosophy of the duration library).

blockquote.pre: duration<double> d(3.5); duration<int> i = d; // implicit truncation, should not compile

discussion.p: This intent was codified in the example implementation which drove this proposal but I failed to accurately translate the code into the specification in this regard.

blockquote.p: We agree with the proposed resolution.

discussion.blockquote: Moved from Tentatively Ready to Open only because the wording needs to be improved for enable_if type constraining, possibly following Robert's formula.
Not completely addressed by . Move to Ready.

blockquote.pre: template <class Rep2, class Period2> duration(const duration<Rep2, Period2>& d);
blockquote.blockquote: -4- Requires: treat_as_floating_point<rep>::value shall be true or both ratio_divide<Period2, period>::type::den shall be 1 and treat_as_floating_point<Rep2>::value shall be false. Diagnostic required. [Note: This requirement prevents implicit truncation error when converting between integral-based duration types. Such a construction could easily lead to confusion about the value of the duration. -- end note]
